Homemade Mac and Cheese with Cheddar

Jump to Recipe

Indulge in the ultimate comfort food experience with our Homemade Mac and Cheese recipe, featuring creamy cheddar cheese and perfectly cooked elbow macaroni. This classic dish is not only a staple in American cuisine but also a favorite among families and food lovers alike. Whether you're looking for a quick weeknight dinner or a crowd-pleasing side dish for gatherings, this mac and cheese recipe is sure to satisfy. With just a handful of ingredients, including buttery roux, rich milk, and the star of the show—sharp cheddar cheese—you can create a luscious and decadent meal that rivals any restaurant's offering. Plus, it’s easy to customize! Add your favorite toppings or mix-ins like crispy bacon, breadcrumbs, or vegetables for a personal touch. Get ready to make a cheesy masterpiece that will have everyone asking for seconds!

Ingredients

elbow macaroni

Elbow macaroni is the classic choice for mac and cheese due to its shape, which holds cheese sauce well. If you don't have elbow macaroni, you can substitute with small shells or cavatappi. For a healthier option, consider whole wheat or gluten-free pasta, adjusting the cooking time as necessary.

cheddar cheese (shredded)

Cheddar cheese gives mac and cheese its signature flavor. For a more complex taste, try mixing sharp cheddar with mild cheddar or other cheeses like Gruyère, Monterey Jack, or even a touch of blue cheese. If you're looking for a lower-fat option, use reduced-fat cheddar, but be aware that it may not melt as smoothly.

milk

Whole milk is ideal for a rich and creamy sauce, but you can use 2% milk or even evaporated milk for a creamier texture. For a non-dairy version, almond milk or oat milk can work, but be sure to check for unsweetened varieties to avoid unwanted flavors.

butter

Butter adds richness to the sauce. You can substitute with margarine or olive oil if you're looking for a healthier fat. For a more pronounced flavor, use flavored butters or clarify butter to enhance the dish further.

all-purpose flour

All-purpose flour is used to make the roux, which thickens the cheese sauce. For a gluten-free version, use cornstarch or a gluten-free flour blend, adjusting the amount slightly since they may thicken differently.

salt

Salt enhances all the flavors in the dish. If you want to reduce sodium, consider using low-sodium salt or simply tasting as you go to manage the amount. Adding a pinch of smoked salt can also provide a unique flavor twist.

black pepper

Black pepper adds a nice spice to the dish. If you prefer a milder flavor, you can reduce the amount or use white pepper instead, which has a more subtle taste. For added depth, try freshly cracked black pepper.

garlic powder

Garlic powder contributes a nice flavor. Fresh minced garlic can be used instead for a more vibrant taste, but reduce the amount to about 1/4 teaspoon as fresh garlic is stronger. Alternatively, onion powder can also be added for a different flavor profile.

Cooking Steps

  • Step 1: Cook the Macaroni

    Boil a large pot of salted water. Add 2 cups of elbow macaroni and cook according to the package instructions until al dente, usually about 7-9 minutes. Stir occasionally to prevent sticking. Once cooked, drain the macaroni in a colander and set aside.

  • Step 2: Make the Roux

    In a medium saucepan over medium heat, melt 2 tablespoons of butter. Once melted, add 2 tablespoons of all-purpose flour. Stir constantly for about 1 minute to create a roux, which will help thicken your cheese sauce. Be careful not to let it brown.

  • Step 3: Add Milk and Thicken Sauce

    Gradually whisk in 2 cups of milk into the roux, ensuring there are no lumps. Continue stirring constantly until the mixture thickens and starts to bubble, about 5-7 minutes. This is the base for your cheese sauce.

  • Step 4: Season the Sauce

    Once the sauce has thickened, add 1 teaspoon of salt, 1/2 teaspoon of black pepper, and 1/2 teaspoon of garlic powder. Stir well to combine all the flavors.

  • Step 5: Add Cheddar Cheese

    Remove the saucepan from heat and stir in 2 cups of shredded cheddar cheese. Mix until the cheese is fully melted and the sauce is smooth. This is where your mac and cheese gets its creamy texture.

  • Step 6: Combine Macaroni and Cheese Sauce

    In a large bowl, combine the cooked macaroni with the cheese sauce. Stir until the pasta is evenly coated. Make sure every piece of macaroni is covered in that delicious cheese sauce.

  • Step 7: Serve and Enjoy

    Transfer the mac and cheese to a serving dish or individual bowls. Serve hot and enjoy your homemade mac and cheese! For added flavor, consider topping with breadcrumbs and baking for a crispy finish.

Frequently Asked Questions

What does 'al dente' mean when cooking pasta?

'Al dente' means the pasta is cooked but still firm to the bite. It usually takes 1-2 minutes less than the package cooking time. This is important so the pasta doesn't become mushy when mixed with the cheese sauce.

How do I know when my butter is fully melted without burning it?

Melt the butter over medium heat and watch for it to foam. Once the foam subsides and the butter is clear, it’s fully melted. Stir it gently to prevent burning.

What is a roux and why do I need it for mac and cheese?

A roux is a mixture of fat (like butter) and flour cooked together. It helps thicken sauces, giving your mac and cheese a creamy texture. Cook it for about a minute to eliminate the raw flour taste.

How can I prevent my cheese sauce from becoming lumpy?

Gradually whisk in the milk while stirring constantly to keep the mixture smooth. Make sure the heat is medium, not too high, to avoid cooking the cheese too quickly.

What type of cheddar cheese should I use?

You can use sharp, medium, or mild cheddar cheese based on your taste preference. Sharp cheddar gives a stronger flavor, while mild is creamier and less intense.

Can I add other ingredients to my mac and cheese?

Absolutely! Feel free to add cooked bacon, vegetables (like broccoli or peas), or spices (like paprika or mustard) to enhance flavor and nutrition.

What should I do if I accidentally overcooked the macaroni?

If the macaroni is slightly overcooked, it can still work. Just keep in mind that it may be softer. Mix it gently with the cheese sauce to avoid further breaking down the pasta.

How should I store leftover mac and cheese?

Store leftovers in an airtight container in the fridge for up to 3-5 days. You can reheat it in the microwave or on the stovetop with a splash of milk to restore creaminess.

How do I clean up spills or messes safely in the kitchen?

Always clean spills immediately to prevent slips. Use a damp cloth for sticky spills and a dry cloth for liquids. Keep a first aid kit handy for any minor kitchen accidents.

What is the best way to serve homemade mac and cheese?

Serve it hot, straight from the pot, for the best texture. You can also sprinkle some extra cheddar or breadcrumbs on top and broil it for a crispy crust!

Additional Information

Dietary Considerations

For a gluten-free version, substitute elbow macaroni with gluten-free pasta options like chickpea or quinoa pasta. For a plant-based alternative, use dairy-free cheese, almond milk, and a vegan butter substitute. Be mindful of portion sizes for those on a calorie-restricted diet, and consider serving with a side of vegetables to balance the meal.

Pairings

Pair your homemade mac and cheese with crispy bacon bits or diced ham for a meatier option. For a vegetarian twist, consider adding sautéed broccoli or spinach. A fresh green salad dressed with a light vinaigrette complements the richness of the mac and cheese. For beverages, an ice-cold lager or a fruity white wine like Sauvignon Blanc works well, while a refreshing lemonade or iced tea can also balance the dish.

Serving Suggestions

Serve the mac and cheese hot, straight from the oven or stovetop, in individual bowls for a cozy presentation. Garnish with a sprinkle of additional shredded cheddar or a dash of paprika for color. To elevate the dish, consider adding a crunchy topping by mixing breadcrumbs with a bit of melted butter and baking until golden brown before serving. For a fun touch, serve with a side of hot sauce for those who enjoy a kick!

Homemade Mac and Cheese with Cheddar

30 min
$8
400 kcal
Difficulty: 20%
Servings: 4

Allergens:

DairyGluten

Dietary Tags:

Vegetarian

Cuisine:

American

Course:

Tags:

Comfort FoodQuickCheesy

Description

Creamy, cheesy, and comforting - the ultimate mac and cheese experience!

Ingredients

  • elbow macaroni: 2 cups
  • cheddar cheese (shredded): 2 cups
  • milk: 2 cups
  • butter: 2 tablespoons
  • all-purpose flour: 2 tablespoons
  • salt: 1 teaspoon
  • black pepper: 1/2 teaspoon
  • garlic powder: 1/2 teaspoon

11/21/2024
